lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters, dates, and weather mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before listening, ask students to predict the date and weather they might hear. During listening, they check or change their answers.
stretchStrategies: In groups, students change the story ending by adding a new date and weather, then act out or present the “next chapter” to the class.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Assign story roles. Students rehearse with SB open, then close books and act out with gestures. Ask follow-up Qs: “What was the weather?”
stretchStrategies: In groups, students change the story ending by adding a new date and weather, then act out or present the “next chapter” to the class.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or performing it.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Show the final story scene and ask: “What happens next month?” Students draw or write a new scene using date/weather language.
stretchStrategies: In groups, students change the story ending by adding a new date and weather, then act out or present the “next chapter” to the class.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
